Exaggerate: The claim may exaggerate the speed of the hoverboard, as the company claims a maximum speed of 87 miles per hour, while the headline claims over 103 miles per hour.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient evidence or data to support the speed of the hoverboard.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the video is genuine and not an artful hoax, which many people suspect.
Exist alternative explanation: There is an alternative explanation that the video may be a hoax or edited to create the illusion of flying on a hoverboard.
Understate: The claim may understate the speed of the hoverboard, as the company claims a maximum speed of 87 miles per hour, but the video suggests it can go faster.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that only Franky Zapata can pilot the Flyboard Air, according to the company's website.
